metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML Soap
Why SOAP?
It is important for web applications to be able to communicate over the Internet.
content.html: It is important for web applications to be able to communicate over the Internet.

content.text: The best way to communicate between applications is over HTTP, because HTTP is supported by all Internet browsers and servers. SOAP was created to accomplish this.
content.html: The best way to communicate between applications is over HTTP, because HTTP is supported by all Internet browsers and servers. SOAP was created to accomplish this.

content.text: SOAP provides a way to communicate between applications running on different operating systems, with different technologies and programming languages.
content.html: SOAP provides a way to communicate between applications running on different operating systems, with different technologies and programming languages.

content.text: SOAP Building Blocks
A SOAP message is an ordinary XML document containing the following elements:
content.html: A SOAP message is an ordinary XML document containing the following elements:

content.text: All the elements above are declared in the default namespace for the SOAP envelope:
content.html: All the elements above are declared in the default namespace for the SOAP envelope:

content.text: http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope
content.html: http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope

content.text: and the default namespace for SOAP encoding and data types is:
content.html: and the default namespace for SOAP encoding and data types is:

content.text: http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding
content.html: http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding

content.text: Syntax Rules
Here are some important syntax rules:
content.html: Here are some important syntax rules:

content.text: Skeleton SOAP Message

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Header>
...
</soap:Header>

<soap:Body>
...
  <soap:Fault>
  ...
  </soap:Fault>
</soap:Body>

</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The SOAP Envelope Element
The required SOAP Envelope element is the root element of a SOAP message. This element defines the XML document as a SOAP message.
content.html: The required SOAP Envelope element is the root element of a SOAP message. This element defines the XML document as a SOAP message.

content.text: Example

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">
  ...
  Message information goes here
  ...
</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The xmlns:soap Namespace
Notice the xmlns:soap namespace in the example above. It should always have the value of: "http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope".
content.html: Notice the xmlns:soap namespace in the example above. It should always have the value of: "http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope".

content.text: The namespace defines the Envelope as a SOAP Envelope.
content.html: The namespace defines the Envelope as a SOAP Envelope.

content.text: If a different namespace is used, the application generates an error and discards the message.
content.html: If a different namespace is used, the application generates an error and discards the message.

content.text: The encodingStyle Attribute
The encodingStyle attribute is used to define the data types used in the document. This attribute may appear on any SOAP element, and applies to the element's contents and all child elements.
content.html: The encodingStyle attribute is used to define the data types used in the document. This attribute may appear on any SOAP element, and applies to the element's contents and all child elements.

content.text: A SOAP message has no default encoding.
content.html: A SOAP message has no default encoding.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: soap:encodingStyle="URI"

content.text: Example

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">
  ...
  Message information goes here
  ...
</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The SOAP Header Element
The optional SOAP Header element contains application-specific information (like authentication, payment, etc) about the SOAP message.
content.html: The optional SOAP Header element contains application-specific information (like authentication, payment, etc) about the SOAP message.

content.text: If the Header element is present, it must be the first child element of the Envelope element.
content.html: If the Header element is present, it must be the first child element of the Envelope element.

content.text: Note: All immediate child elements of the Header element must be namespace-qualified.
content.html: Note: All immediate child elements of the Header element must be namespace-qualified.

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Header>
  <m:Trans xmlns:m="https://www.w3schools.com/transaction/"
  soap:mustUnderstand="1">234
  </m:Trans>
</soap:Header>
...
...
</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The example above contains a header with a "Trans" element, a "mustUnderstand" attribute with a value of 1, and a value of 234.
content.html: The example above contains a header with a "Trans" element, a "mustUnderstand" attribute with a value of 1, and a value of 234.

content.text: SOAP defines three attributes in the default namespace. These attributes are: mustUnderstand, actor, and encodingStyle.
content.html: SOAP defines three attributes in the default namespace. These attributes are: mustUnderstand, actor, and encodingStyle.

content.text: The attributes defined in the SOAP Header defines how a recipient should process the SOAP message.
content.html: The attributes defined in the SOAP Header defines how a recipient should process the SOAP message.

content.text: The mustUnderstand Attribute
The SOAP mustUnderstand attribute can be used to indicate whether a header entry is mandatory or optional for the recipient to process.
content.html: The SOAP mustUnderstand attribute can be used to indicate whether a header entry is mandatory or optional for the recipient to process.

content.text: If you add mustUnderstand="1" to a child element of the Header element it indicates that the receiver processing the Header must recognize the element. If the receiver does not recognize the element it will fail when processing the Header.
content.html: If you add mustUnderstand="1" to a child element of the Header element it indicates that the receiver processing the Header must recognize the element. If the receiver does not recognize the element it will fail when processing the Header.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: soap:mustUnderstand="0|1"

content.text: Example

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Header>
  <m:Trans xmlns:m="https://www.w3schools.com/transaction/"
  soap:mustUnderstand="1">234
  </m:Trans>
</soap:Header>
...
...
</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The actor Attribute

A SOAP message may travel from a sender to a receiver by passing different endpoints along the message path. However, not all parts of a SOAP message may be intended for the ultimate endpoint, instead, it may be intended for one or more of the endpoints on the message path.
content.html: A SOAP message may travel from a sender to a receiver by passing different endpoints along the message path. However, not all parts of a SOAP message may be intended for the ultimate endpoint, instead, it may be intended for one or more of the endpoints on the message path.

content.text: The SOAP actor attribute is used to address the Header element to a specific endpoint.
content.html: The SOAP actor attribute is used to address the Header element to a specific endpoint.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: soap:actor="URI"

content.text: Example

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Header>
  <m:Trans xmlns:m="https://www.w3schools.com/transaction/"
  soap:actor="https://www.w3schools.com/code/">234
  </m:Trans>
</soap:Header>
...
...
</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The encodingStyle Attribute
The encodingStyle attribute is used to define the data types used in the document. This attribute may appear on any SOAP element, and it will apply to that element's contents and all child elements.
content.html: The encodingStyle attribute is used to define the data types used in the document. This attribute may appear on any SOAP element, and it will apply to that element's contents and all child elements.

content.text: A SOAP message has no default encoding.
content.html: A SOAP message has no default encoding.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: soap:encodingStyle="URI"

content.text: The SOAP Body Element
The required SOAP Body element contains the actual SOAP message intended for the ultimate endpoint of the message.
content.html: The required SOAP Body element contains the actual SOAP message intended for the ultimate endpoint of the message.

content.text: Immediate child elements of the SOAP Body element may be namespace-qualified.
content.html: Immediate child elements of the SOAP Body element may be namespace-qualified.

content.text: Example

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Body>
  <m:GetPrice xmlns:m="https://www.w3schools.com/prices">
    <m:Item>Apples</m:Item>
  </m:GetPrice>
</soap:Body>

</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The example above requests the price of apples. Note that the m:GetPrice and the Item elements above are application-specific elements. They are not a part of the SOAP namespace.
content.html: The example above requests the price of apples. Note that the m:GetPrice and the Item elements above are application-specific elements. They are not a part of the SOAP namespace.

content.text: A SOAP response could look something like this:
content.html: A SOAP response could look something like this:

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Body>
  <m:GetPriceResponse xmlns:m="https://www.w3schools.com/prices">
    <m:Price>1.90</m:Price>
  </m:GetPriceResponse>
</soap:Body>

</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The SOAP Fault Element
The optional SOAP Fault element is used to indicate error messages.
content.html: The optional SOAP Fault element is used to indicate error messages.

content.text: The SOAP Fault element holds errors and status information for a SOAP message.
content.html: The SOAP Fault element holds errors and status information for a SOAP message.

content.text: If a Fault element is present, it must appear as a child element of the Body element. A Fault element can only appear once in a SOAP message.
content.html: If a Fault element is present, it must appear as a child element of the Body element. A Fault element can only appear once in a SOAP message.

content.text: The SOAP Fault element has the following sub elements:
content.html: The SOAP Fault element has the following sub elements:

content.code_html:
Sub Element Description
<faultcode> A code for identifying the fault
<faultstring> A human readable explanation of the fault
<faultactor> Information about who caused the fault to happen
<detail>

Holds application specific error information related to the Body element

content.text: SOAP Fault Codes
The faultcode values defined below must be used in the faultcode element when describing faults:
content.html: The faultcode values defined below must be used in the faultcode element when describing faults:

content.code_html:
Error Description
VersionMismatch Found an invalid namespace for the SOAP Envelope element
MustUnderstand An immediate child element of the Header element, with the mustUnderstand attribute set to "1", was not understood
Client The message was incorrectly formed or contained incorrect information
Server There was a problem with the server so the message could not proceed

content.text: The HTTP Protocol
HTTP communicates over TCP/IP. An HTTP client connects to an HTTP server using TCP. After establishing a connection, the client can send an HTTP request message to the server:
content.html: HTTP communicates over TCP/IP. An HTTP client connects to an HTTP server using TCP. After establishing a connection, the client can send an HTTP request message to the server:

content.code:
POST /item HTTP/1.1

Host: 189.123.255.239

Content-Type: text/plain

Content-Length: 200
content.code_html:
POST /item HTTP/1.1
Host: 189.123.255.239
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Length: 200

content.text: The server then processes the request and sends an HTTP response back to the client. The response contains a status code that indicates the status of the request:
content.html: The server then processes the request and sends an HTTP response back to the client. The response contains a status code that indicates the status of the request:

content.code_html:
200 OK
Content-Type: text/plain
Content-Length: 200

content.text: In the example above, the server returned a status code of 200. This is the standard success code for HTTP.
content.html: In the example above, the server returned a status code of 200. This is the standard success code for HTTP.

content.text: If the server could not decode the request, it could have returned something like this:
content.html: If the server could not decode the request, it could have returned something like this:

content.code_html:
400 Bad Request
Content-Length: 0

content.text: SOAP Binding

The SOAP specification defines the structure of the SOAP messages, not how they are exchanged. This gap is filled by what is called "SOAP Bindings". SOAP bindings are mechanisms which allow SOAP messages to be effectively exchanged using a transport protocol.
content.html: The SOAP specification defines the structure of the SOAP messages, not how they are exchanged. This gap is filled by what is called "SOAP Bindings". SOAP bindings are mechanisms which allow SOAP messages to be effectively exchanged using a transport protocol.

content.text: Most SOAP implementations provide bindings for common transport protocols, such as HTTP or SMTP.
content.html: Most SOAP implementations provide bindings for common transport protocols, such as HTTP or SMTP.

content.text: HTTP is synchronous and widely used. A SOAP HTTP request specifies at least two HTTP headers: Content-Type and Content-Length.
content.html: HTTP is synchronous and widely used. A SOAP HTTP request specifies at least two HTTP headers: Content-Type and Content-Length.

content.text: SMTP is asynchronous and is used in last resort or particular cases.
content.html: SMTP is asynchronous and is used in last resort or particular cases.

content.text: Java implementations of SOAP usually provide a specific binding for the JMS (Java Messaging System) protocol.
content.html: Java implementations of SOAP usually provide a specific binding for the JMS (Java Messaging System) protocol.

content.text: Content-Type
The Content-Type header for a SOAP request and response defines the MIME type for the message and the character encoding (optional) used for the XML body of the request or response.
content.html: The Content-Type header for a SOAP request and response defines the MIME type for the message and the character encoding (optional) used for the XML body of the request or response.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: Content-Type: MIMEType; charset=character-encoding

content.text: Example

content.code_html:
POST /item HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8

content.text: Content-Length
The Content-Length header for a SOAP request and response specifies the number of bytes in the body of the request or response.
content.html: The Content-Length header for a SOAP request and response specifies the number of bytes in the body of the request or response.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: Content-Length: bytes

content.text: Example

content.code:
POST /item HTTP/1.1

Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8

Content-Length: 250
content.code_html:
POST /item HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 250

content.text: A SOAP Example

In the example below, a GetStockPrice request is sent to a server. The request has a StockName parameter, and a Price parameter that will be returned in the response. The namespace for the function is defined in "http://www.example.org/stock".
content.html: In the example below, a GetStockPrice request is sent to a server. The request has a StockName parameter, and a Price parameter that will be returned in the response. The namespace for the function is defined in "http://www.example.org/stock".

content.text: A SOAP request:

content.code:
POST /InStock HTTP/1.1

Host: www.example.org

Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8

Content-Length: nnn


<?xml version="1.0"?>


<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">


<soap:Body xmlns:m="http://www.example.org/stock">

<m:GetStockPrice>


<m:StockName>IBM</m:StockName>

</m:GetStockPrice>

</soap:Body>


</soap:Envelope>
content.code_html:
POST /InStock HTTP/1.1
Host: www.example.org
Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: nnn

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Body xmlns:m="http://www.example.org/stock">
  <m:GetStockPrice>
    <m:StockName>IBM</m:StockName>
  </m:GetStockPrice>
</soap:Body>

</soap:Envelope>

content.text: The SOAP response:

content.code:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8

Content-Length: nnn


<?xml version="1.0"?>


<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">


<soap:Body xmlns:m="http://www.example.org/stock">


<m:GetStockPriceResponse>


<m:Price>34.5</m:Price>


</m:GetStockPriceResponse>

</soap:Body>


</soap:Envelope>
content.code_html:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: nnn

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<soap:Envelope
xmlns:soap="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope"
soap:encodingStyle="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-encoding">

<soap:Body xmlns:m="http://www.example.org/stock">
  <m:GetStockPriceResponse>
    <m:Price>34.5</m:Price>
  </m:GetStockPriceResponse>
</soap:Body>

</soap:Envelope>
